# Carbon capture for semi-trucks
Your browser does not support the video tag. 
## Emissions reduction  that generates revenue
How it works 
We're building a device that captures a semi-truck's carbon emissions directly from the tailpipe.
Our device will mount on the back of the truck, attach to its tailpipe, and filter the carbon emissions out of its exhaust.
The driver will offload the captured, compressed CO2 while they refuel.
Then, we'll sell our high-purity, liquid CO2 to end-users, or sell credits for permanently sequestering it underground in EPA-certified wells.
We'll share the revenue from the captured CO2 with our customers, so the device will create a new revenue stream for our customers while reducing their emissions.

01 Bolt on

03 Sequester 
Our device will bolt onto a Class 8 tractor and attach to the outlet of its aftertreatment system. Our mounting system will be designed to make no permanent changes that affect the operation of the truck. 1 Our device will fit between the back of the tractor and the front of the trailer, and it will not impact the turning radius of the tractor. 2
Our device will act like a giant filter, using carbon scrubbing technology to filter CO2 out of the exhaust. The captured CO2 is automatically compressed and stored in onboard tanks. 1 If the tanks fill up before the driver gets a chance to offload the captured CO2, the device will automatically bypass so the truck can keep rolling. 2 Our device will be partially powered by the truck's exhaust heat, minimizing its impact on the truck's fuel economy. It will also be designed to never exceed the allowable back pressure on the truck's engine. 
Drivers will dump the captured CO2 by connecting the device to an offload tank with a hose. Offloading will be designed to take less time than it takes to refuel. 1 For round trips, we'll install offload tanks at customers' distribution centers, and for long-haul routes, offload tanks are coming to a truck stop near you.  Once an offload tank fills up, we'll pick up the high-purity, liquid CO2 with a tanker truck and deliver it to end-users or permanently sequester it underground in an EPA-certified well.

Once an offload tank fills up, we pick up the CO2 with a tanker truck and deliver it to concrete producers or other end-users who store it away for a long time. ### Remora: Capturing Carbon from Semi-Trucks

**Overview:**
Founded in 2020 and based in Detroit, MI, Remora is tackling carbon emissions from semi-trucks head-on. Imagine a device that not only captures CO2 directly from a truck's tailpipe but also turns this environmental effort into a profit opportunity for truck operators.

**Mission:**
Remora’s goal is straightforward—reduce emissions from heavy-duty trucks while generating revenue. They achieve this through a patented device that filters carbon from exhaust gases, giving trucking companies a new income stream by selling the captured CO2 or using it to earn carbon credits.

**How It Works:**
1. **Installation:** The device is designed to easily bolt onto Class 8 trucks without making permanent modifications.
2. **Capture:** It acts like a giant filter, scrubbing the exhaust gases and compressing the CO2 for storage.
3. **Offloading:** During refueling, truck drivers can offload the captured CO2 quickly, minimizing downtime, while Remora manages the transport of this CO2 to end-users or for permanent underground storage.

**Business Model:**
By sharing a portion of the revenue generated from the captured carbon with their clients, Remora allows trucking companies to not only comply with environmental regulations but also to financially benefit from reducing their carbon footprint.

**Team and Backing:**
With a growing team of 45, Remora is supported by notable investors including Y Combinator, Lowercarbon Capital, and Union Square Ventures. One of their group partners is Gustaf Alstromer, a key player in the startup ecosystem.

**Current Focus:**
Remora is actively engaged in product development and partnerships. With installations at logistics hubs and future plans for offloading stations at truck stops, they are poised to be a significant player in the climate tech space.

**Conclusion:**
Remora is more than just a company; it's part of a movement towards sustainable freight transport. They blend innovation with real-world practicality, making it easier for trucking companies to contribute to a greener planet—all while earning extra income. Check them out at [remoracarbon.com](https://www.remoracarbon.com) for more information.
